This is a compact turnout control that is self latching. I made this to use with my hand built N scale turnouts. It is about the same footprint as the popular Caboose Hobbies ground throw, but about half the height. Added a second narrow style base - better to fit between parallel tracks.
01-03-2017 Moved model into Tinkercad to make revisions easier. Resized pivot peg for more strength. Resized & relocated several holes for better fit. All parts in a single file. Separate objects to remove the base option you will not use.
03-24-2017 Added individual files for each part.

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.200 or .150 layers

Infill:

25% - 30%

Notes:

You will need a well adjusted machine for these tiny parts - especially to get the holes and the pivot peg to print. You may need a 1/16" drill for the pivot hole in the rocker and the cap, and a 1/32" drill for the tiny hole in the rocker arm for the control wire.
The cap will dovetail onto the base, but I recommend a tiny amount of CA glue around the dovetail to keep the cap secure.
Parts assembled - cap glued Handle flipped to other position Underside - showing indexing arms and pivot peg support
Developed the design in Sketchup and my 3D printer, starting with the original design of how to build a latching lever, then optimizing the base for support and clearances to get the tension right.

title: Sunhokey Prusa i3 Universal x-carriage, direct drive or bowden

description.text:
This is an X-carriage designed for the acrylic framed Sunhokey prusa i3. A universal design where you can use it as a bowden tube setup or as a direct drive with the original extruder.
You'll need to mount the extruder upside down on its piece. The hole in the idler arm is just big enough to securely fit the piece of ptfe tube to hold it up next to the gear. You can use a shorter motor with the same hole pattern to reduce weight. You might need to use full steps to get the required torque.

I've been printing with it now for a month and it works well. The clip is mandatory for retractions. You don't need a bowden coupler at the top either, that picture is from before I printed the awesome spool holder from davidwyl, check his design out, it's great for the sunhokey frame.

  • UPDATE: Added a clip to retain the right side of the setup during and after retraction. The clip needs a bit of filing afterward to make it fit right. If anyone wants, I can update the right side of the motor mount to accommodate the clip better.

  • UPDATE: The sensor we've order has arrived and I quickly drew up a holder for it to mount to the new hole in the left side instead of a cooling fan. I'm using a separate house fan and a lower bed temp for layers after 2, 45 c to be exact. It seems to work alright putting models closer to the fan. Haven't tested any real overhangs that way though. No stress tests.

I'm using an E3D v6 so the length of my tube vs yours will vary based on hotend used. I mount the extruder first with the tube hanging down, then fit the hotend up the tube and fix the metal mount up. MAKE SURE TO REMOVE THE BOWDEN COUPLER FROM THE TOP OF YOUR HOTEND. If you don't you will have a bad time removing the tube later.

The carriage mount uses the stock rod bushings that come with the printer, and the arrow goes down.

Adjust the tension arm by twisting the nut up tight until the spring is just under tension, maybe a turn more.
Oil the OUTSIDE of the ptfe tube if it's a p.i.t.a. to push in, I didn't have to resort to pliers.

Printer:

Dildometer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

Remove the support.
On the side without the large square cutout you'll have to file a spot down where the head of the hotend mount screw will be. The inside of the left leg of the mount. Also file down the 2mm portion of the clip to fit between extruder and its mount. Should be able to slide forward and off, or back on easily, but still retain pressure after retractions.

Post a make after printing, I'd love to see my design being used by others.
Fusion 360

Here is the current code, information and files for my Sainsmart 4WD robot build. The code is not optimized whatsoever but functions well enough at this point. So many people have asked for the code due to troubles- I decided to post it here. You will need to modify the code to suit your setup and connections but this should provide a baseline for anyone struggling with their robot. Good luck in your build. If this helped you please consider leaving a comment or thumbs up on my YouTube videos. There are several covering much of this robot build. For future updates please consider subscribing. I ask 2 things of anyone who uses this:
  • Give credit when possible to those who help you
  • Improve and share code to better the experience for everyone
    • Updated code an instructions:
    http://blog.mkme.org/index.php/arduino-sainsmart-4wd-robot/ Channel:
    https://www.youtube.com/user/Shadow5549 This robot build and my other Arduino videos:
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Bpht2otFoF4&list=PLxyM2a_cfnzh9sbbEMFvFAGvNKfSElkvC Another:
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sztUkGO6Fuo Unboxing:
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BD3JAdnVosg&list=UUTo55-kBvyy5Y1X_DTgrTOQ Most recent Video:
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7sN_mxAh7Og Cheers! Note:
    If you are here due to a high level of frustration with the programming, hardware and/or components- fear not. You are not alone. Check out the below vid (no link so as to not say bad things about anyone's products). I just about went crazy when I first built this thing- It DOES get easier. Hence me sharing the code ;) Youtube:
    watch?v=7U4yzxh0IMQ&list=UUTo55-kBvyy5Y1X_DTgrTOQ Update V9 Code:
    Updated to better deal with corners and direction change

Simply edit the code to suit your pin configuration and comment out any items you don't want to include.  From there you should have a decent base to develop your robot from!  
Mount for distance sensor servo and sensor itself can be found on Thingiverse- links to be updated.  
If you get your robot working using this code or any mods/info found here- please share with me via YouTube. I would be truly excited to see your creation.  
Cheers

comments.text: It actually works pretty good.  A lot of people have it working just fine.  I've noticed some discrepancies now and again with mine- but suspect that is code based.  I think with the new libraries etc- it should be VERY capable.  At the speed these things can sample at- you should be able to do it while moving even.  Overall mine seems to be pretty good considering how crude the code currently is :) Cheers.

description.text: Another gimbal I've designed. This one uses different bearings (print bearings covers (2) and gimbal axles (2)).
Bearing covers to go with the Gimbal (2) I designed. They are to be used with a bearing that has an outer diameter of 22mm, inner diameter of 10mm and a thickness of 7mm.

This set of stackable weight blocks are designed to be used as a teaching tool for math, weight, and measurement skills.  
The blocks interlock on the top and bottom for easy stacking and are available in grams and ounces, each block is marked on top with it's unit type and the weight is imprinted on it's face.  
They should be printed with 2 shells and 100% infill to reach the desired weights (note: my home scale does not allow partial gram measurements, if you find any weights to be off please let me know and I'll make some adjustments). No support material is required.

comments.text: Very clever. Thank you for posting this! I might print a few extra for my teacher friends.

description.text:
A friend asked me to print this for his HTC Vive, I thought it took way to long to print and used too much plastic so I made it a bit lighter and quicker to print. The strength feels great with 20% of the plastic used (25% infill) compared to the original design. It's not been tested yet with the actual headset, so please be patient until my good friend has tested this out.
Or print it and test it if you want. I've printed it both in PLA as well as PETG, I think the PETG version will hold up best but the PLA version feels strong as well.

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

25%

Assembly

Holes made for 4 x M5 screws, you probably just need to screws but that's up to you.

comments.text: Holds the headset really well, but the sharp edges on the top chew at the headset foam over time unless you're incredibly careful.  I'd highly recommend filleting them even slightly to reduce the wear.

comments.text:
I printed it and tested it. For sure works, but because I modified my headset with a welding setup and use vr covers for the face foam, I have to work to get it in to the correct area to rest on.
I will upload a made picture, but I might end up modifying your design to allow it to better enter the headset without the work needed to do it now.
It fits perfect if you have not modified the headset though, so anyone wanting to print a stand that doesn't take 24 hours to print and most likely will have curl issues and fail at 90%, print this one. I used PET for mine at 20% infill and it seems plenty capable of supporting the headset.

description.text: 6 colors Ferrari logo, printed with new version of 6 ways Flux Capacitor

The Sculpt Mode in Blender has been upgraded pretty significantly for 2.5!
To celebrate, I've uploaded some .blend files which are already set up for sculpting.  There'll be a tutorial on the Thingiverse Blog later, but if you've used Blender to do a few things like model scaling, opening one of these in 2.5 should be mostly self-explanatory.
The different files represent different shapes to use as start points.  They all have flat bottoms and so they'll at least start out printable!

1: Get Blender 2.5:
http://www.blender.org/development/release-logs/blender-250/ 2: Open one of the .blend files and start sculpting! Just click anywhere on the model and watch the surface bulge out as though you were sticking clay to it. 3: Try messing with the options on the left side of your screen-- there's mirroring, different sculpt modes, and each mode has options. 4: Export-- Blender 2.5 doesn't support STL yet (email the developers!) but since it has .obj we can get around that. 5: Print!

comments.text:
I did a little searching and ran across documentation that Blender does support STL somehow:
http://www.blender.org/documentation/243PythonDoc/Blender-module.html#Savehttp://www.blender.org/documen...
comments.author: RobotHacker

comments.text: The current version of Blender (2.49) does support STLs, both loading and saving.  But Blender 2.5 alpha, the version I'm recommending for sculpting, doesn't.  The way to get around Blender 2.5's lack of STL format I recommend is actually to save the final mesh as .obj, then load and save to .stl from Blender 2.49.
comments.author: RobotHacker

description.text:
This is a carabiner with a self tightening latch. I designed this and printed it using ABS. The final product is very strong. 
Update: I added a carabiner with a relief for PLA.

1.) Print
2.) Enjoy

comments.text: Hello LT1Pat, as a college engineering report I used these carabiners to test the strengths of different infill percents on a 3-D printer. The tests were at 20%, 40%, 60%, 80%, and 100%. We also compared pricing and time to print. I printed four parts at each infill and tested the strengths. The material was Hatchbox PLA, and the infill shape was a hexagon.
comments.author: Zach12323

comments.text: I tried printing this at 20% infill in ABS at first, and while it worked pretty well, it snapped at an interior void when I really pushed on it. Â I tried it again at 50% infill and it seems a lot stronger, but it's also a lot harder to push open. Â So I'd imagine somewhere around 30-40% infill would be the sweet spot between being strong enough to not break easily, and flexible enough to open without having to push too hard.
comments.author: JennaSys

comments.text: I had to scale the PLA model up to 1.3x or so to get Cura (set to 2 perimeters of 0.4 mm) to do a good job of slicing the area around the relief.
comments.author: LawrenceJohnston

comments.text: The natual "grain" from printing does a pretty good job of preventing side-slip, but a slight triangular profile and recess in the latch face would be nice. Pritned better than I expected! Testing it on a laptop bag shoulder strap.
comments.author: AUGuru

comments.text: Scary job for a first test!
comments.author: AUGuru

comments.text: I had printed 4 designs before printing this one to find the weakness of each one. The earlier designs could be broken but everyone who has tried to break this one couldn't. I may try putting it on a tensile strength tester to see where the breaking point is but I would guess around 100lb.
comments.author: LT1Pat

comments.text:
I have done a test on it at 100% resulting with failure at 125 LBS and at 80% failing at 100LBs both at 100%infill
Very impressive.
comments.author: LT1Pat

The tests were at 20%, 40%, 60%, 80%, and 100%. We also compared pricing and time to print. I printed four parts at each infill and tested the strengths. author: tomasf

description.text:
Wild, sure. Wacky, check. A little nuts, most definitely! You may seen the products that allow you to attach your SLR lenses to your iPhone, but why settle for that when you can mount your whole SLR on your iPhone!
Now when your friend shows up with a SLR lens on their iPhone, you can pull out your iPhone with SLR attached. What can be better than that!
Note: This has only been tested with a Nikon D3100.

• Print out slrMount.stl.
  • Place an iPhone in the part.
  • Attach part onto the eyepiece of your SLR.
  • Take awe-inspiring photos using a 8MP camera through a 14.2MP (If you are using a D3100) camera, that end up being around 0.68MP because of scaling.

description.text:
This is an ultra lightweight 90mm frame for 8.5mm brushed motors.

I originally designed it to be made of a 1mm carbon fiber plate (video soon). But this can also be printed. For this, I suggest 2 or 3 mm height in ABS. ABS will bend and not break like with PLA giving you more opportunity to crash :)

The motor mounts are exactly 8.5 mm diameter, for this I use double sided tape in the motors and then insert it in the motor mounts (images soon).

Use the dxf for ordering it to be made of carbon fiber. Notice the orientation of the fibers in the image example, this is very important since the direction of the fibers determine the rigidity of the frame!

title: Flat Box / FlatField for Astrophotography - English Version

description.text:
Version Française : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1841213

After i bought my first telescope, i looked a lot of forums to find a plan of solid flatbox, and I didn't find.
I have decided to modelise it. At the end... I thought : why not share a customisable flatblox with all the community of astro photographer?
And here it is !

WARNING ! The 3D printers have some issues : they usually make smaller holes than planned. I recommend you to make a printing test with this customizable part : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1841206

The box is in 4 parts (you just have to "Split Object" on repetier host or in another software):
1) Floor (optional but recommended Supports)
2) Walls (As the cylinder walls will surely too thick. Will require sanding for fitting into the slots)
3) Plexiglas holder
4) Roof

Additional material :

  • Bright LED Ribbon Flexible Sticker (length to be defined according to the size of your box)
  • Soldering iron and tin
  • Plexiglass (2-3mm)
  • Tracing paper
  • Glue or Adhesive

The middle parts (2 and 3) are optional, white cardboard for walls is enough, and the plexiglass can be glued (corners) to the bottom piece.

Cut equal stripes (on the dotted lines and in right length), weld them together to create a led carpet into lid (see photos, oh and... when you connect, be careful to not be blinded).

Cut a plate of plexiglass (inside walls) and glue (in the corners) 2 or 3 layers of tracing paper for merge the lights into one uniform source of light.

If you don't print walls and replace them by some cardboard, it will be necessary to make space for the supply cable and close correctly the lid

author: Gepetto

description.text:
I built this small prototype to test several concepts: the tracks made from O-rings, a simple robotic claw, and wireless communications with Arduino. This thing uses:
My robotic claw http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18339
Some parts from my previous designs http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13298
Obijuan's Skymega board http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14197 and battery pack http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5079 See it move at: http://youtu.be/SQqVQEaMtno UPDATE 3/8/2012: The part "front.stl" did not print correctly due to some dangling polygons. I have now replaced it with the correct file! UPDATE 3/13/2012: Uploaded a folder with the scad files. Not very tidy though...

Print and assemble! It's pretty straight fordward. I used O-rings for the tracks (80 mm diameter). You'll need two M6 bolts and nuts, as well as 8 M3 bolts and nuts.
The servo holder is designed for two Futaba S3003 servos. You'll need to modify them for continuous rotation.
Assemble the battery pack with 8 3M nuts and bolts

title: Modular carriage for 40x20 rails (using 3 solid V wheels)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Modular carriage for 40x20 rails. It was designed for Tevo Tarantula to replace stock X Carriage. But it can be used for others with rails 4020 and solid V wheels (24mm)
Update: For origial V-slot please check this remix http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2155251 and use mbot-xc-p1.stl instead of xc-p1.stl

Hotend mount is compatible with mount http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1438795
and pack includes remixed reinforced version of stock Tevo Tarantula mount

Carriage is suppose to use 3 wheels. The top wheel is to be tightened by top bolt. (so just screw tension instead of eccentric nuts)
Use nuts with nylon inserts locking to fix wheels
Basic materials:

  • 3 solid V wheels
  • 3 M5x40mm bolts with 6 nuts with nylon inserts locking for wheels
  • 3 regular or with nylon M5 nuts (just to fix axis M5 bolts)
  • 6 M5 washers
  • 8 M4 12/15mm and 6 M4 10mm (or in total 14 M4 10mm)
  • 1 M4x20mm bolt with M4 nut (with nylon) to fix 3d wheel
    Optional materials:
  • 11 M4 washers
  • 12 M4 nuts for other possible options (just to fix nuts inside in advance)
    Options mount materials:
  • 2 M4 10mm bolts for belt mount
  • 2 M4 10mm bolts with nuts for hotend mount + 1 M4 15mm optional
  • 1 M4 10mm bolt for end stop
  • 2 M4 10mm bolt with 2 T-nuts for end stop stopper

author: henrik_wikstr

description.text:
Thanks Enginecogs, I planned to print and paint this but the base was a little support unfriendly.

I only did three things to this mesh:
1: Cut the base off and made it more print friendly.
2: I smoothed out all the lines and the artifacts that Makeprintable made when it was processed. They come out int he print and you think it's your printer - no it's not. Its makeprintables conversion process. I don't know why it does that, you'd have to ask them, they are working on it apparently.
3: I Tilted the head upward about 15' to make the chin support free.

Will require some supports for the bolts, but at least not for the base or the chin.

This is an approximation of a Tuba Exchange Rose Model LS, internally. Some changes were made to compensate for the fact that it is 3D printed, and the surface will be rough, primarily widening the throat. Due to the need for printing 100% infill, I created a low-volume version that uses less plastic but sacrifices little rigidity.

The "-2" files have smaller throats, allowing less air to be used.
The -2 lightweight is not as light, and more rigid than the regular lightweight, as well as having a narrower throat.

The "lightweight-3" design is simply my personal favorite, with extra ribs where they are needed and a cup wall thickness of only .03" rather than .05", or with standard mouthpieces that you can buy, .25" or greater.

There is also a rib_test file that is a small piece you can use to determine if your printer can print the fine ribs that are necessary.

Scaffolding in the fantasy cityscape is a classic in the video game medium, and now you can do it on tabletop for your chase scenes and city fights.

Also great for structures in caverns, wilderness, dungeons and warehouses. The parts in here could even be used to throw together a guard tower if you like.

This thing is really a ton of parts, so it will take a little modeling skill to put together the pieces you want to build. More then any thing I've released, I can't wait to see the makes for this one, as I think it has a real great range of creative possibilities.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter
  • Facebook

Parts

This model is composed of a bunch of little parts, so you can make a wide variety of scaffolding.

The very basic idea is to take 2 of the same sized scaffolding squares, 4 of the scaffolding cross beams, and some planks. Planks are designed to sit on the cross beams, so planks should be the same length as the scaffolding square used. The scaffolding cross beams should be printed with supports. They have a rectangular backing that properly spaces the squares apart. Glue the cross beams onto the squares, so that the rectangular portion faces inside. For the planks to properly fit, you need to glue the cross beams inside the outer poles on the right and left side of the square.

I prefer to paint the planks separately from the scaffolding. Then I wrap (see below) and finally glue the planks on.

You can add a variety of other features to the scaffolding to make it look better. The cross supports give you the X, and should be glued down on the 4 points where the corners meet on the squares.

You can also use the cross beams as guard rails. Glue them on the outside, with the rectangle facing in.

The various heights (1h, 2h, 3h) help you build more rigid structures of various heights.

Wrapping

After you have painted, but before you glue on the planks, you can make these look substantially better by taking some twine and wrapping all the joints. I used a waxed twine, because they tend to hold their shape better, so it makes it easier to attach and glue then using a purely thread based twine.

Painting

After gluing the beams, but before wrapping or gluing the planks, I spray paint all the parts with a black primer. I presently use Rust-Oleum Painter's Touch 2x Flat Black, which bonds really well with plastic. I've had great experiences with Krylon with Fusion Camouflage Flat Black which is fantastic, but about twice as expensive (However, it's so good, that I use it in place of the primers you can get from Citadel/Army Painter/etc, and I feel it gives a better result at half the price compared to those....)

From there, I paint using Americana paint:

  • Burnt Umber - Covering nearly everything except the deepest crevices
  • Chocolate - Side brushed to get all of the raised surfaces
  • Honey Brown - Dry brushed to get the very tops of raised surfaces
Other Sets
  • Scaffolding Set 1
  • Scaffolding Set 2
  • Ladder Customizer

Changelog

description.text:
Here we have a classic soy-sauce-dipping-dish (or bowl? What's the proper english term for it?)

I recommend using a little support for the elevated bottom of the dish (10% density did it for me). The walls should print well without support but a strong fan is recommended for the overhangs.

If you want to wash it in the dishwasher, consider using a high-temp material like extrudr green-tec, biofila platec or some other HT-PLA. I printed mine in extrudr Fichte (spruce) and it deformed after feeding it to the dishwasher. Gonne try it in green-tec next time.

17.03.2017: reworked the model a little for a less edgy look.

If you wear thick specs like mine and want to stop marking your psvr lenses with your glasses then print 2, these are blu-tacked or double sided taped onto either side of the lens and stop specs from contacting the lens.
Also holds your specs up your nose.
I used designspark mechanical to create and model file is included if you need to modify it.
It does not affect visibility or come near the face, at least not mine, so it can be left fitted for users with no specs as well.

I mean every frame will be different but these are on the extreme size, as are my horrible eyeballs.
I would either file them down to suit or cancel the print part way (if you had a pretty solid infill) or download designspark and modify the model. Or just model something similar, I really made these to suit mine and though sharing it would help others come up with their own solutions.
I want to try a mask of high density foam next.

These are parts that students can print out to solve emergencies in the Space Mission Simulator at the Challenger Learning Center in Tallahassee, FL.

The parts are:

  • Send Transmitter Antenna - Comes in 3 sizes
  • Send Transmitter Base - Comes in 3 sizes

Part number sticker not included.
NGSS CCSS
Using 3D printers as a tool in student-run space missions. When students discover a Send Transmitter on board their probe has been damaged, they must 3D print a replacement.
Use observation and measuring skills to fix the problem The students must work together to inspect the pieces for damage and to measure exact dimensions to 3D print the correct piece for the probe.

You need: 21st Century Probe
21st Century Probe parts
3D printer onboard Sim
Computer conntected to 3D printer with these files inside
Program to use printer that accepts STL files
Filament
Ruler
Task cards and Inventory Log

title: Clamping mount for D-Link 930 series webcam
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A clamping mounting bracket for a D-link 930 series webcam, so you can attach it to any surface (like your 3D printer) without screws.

Two bodies included for different mountings (As I needed more clearance between the printer bed and where the camera ended up.)

Uses the existing ball joint that ships with the camera.

Notes:

The threads printed really tight on the one I made, so you may want to scale down the X and Y of the bolt to 95% to give yourself some wiggle room.

I printed the main body with supports to try to get the best chance for the threads to work.

It's not a flawless design but it does the job.

author: Dakanzla

description.text: Adapter to easily use iSight on conventional microscope

Build both items, I used 20% fill for TOM+Jetty accelerated firmware V3.2
The dimensions are to suit my Bristoline Microscope, x4, x10, x40, x100 (oil immersed) with a 10x eyepiece
Probably have to sand the inside of the adapter slightly to ensure  a snug but not tight, fit. Warning, if fit is too tight then top of the iSight will pop off.
I use Photo Booth on the Mac, especially useful if you go to full screen mode.
The cap is needed to cover the other eyepiece otherwise there is too much extraneous light getting in.
The image is of some dust particles using the x40 lens if you're wondering what it is! Also, if you use an external LED then it works great for top illumination of pcb's etc.

title: SAT replacement part for solar panel

description.text:
These are the 3D printed parts used for Earth Odyssey's 3D printed emergency at the Space Mission Simulator at the Challenger Learning Center of Tallahassee, FL.

It includes:

  • Solar Panel Adapter piece
  • Probe Battery Adapter piece
  • PWR link piece

This is designed to use Elenco Snap Circuits as a base, they are not included.
NGSS CCSS
SAT needs power! The solar panel on the SAT has been damaged; students must 3D print a replacement piece before the SAT is launched.
Use observation and measuring skills to fix the problem The students must work together to inspect the pieces for damage and to measure exact dimensions to 3D print the correct piece for the probe.

You need: SIM3 capable probe
Elenco Snap Circuit solar panel and battery (can be replaced by 3D printed objects of the same dimensions)
3D printer onboard Sim
Computer conntected to 3D printer with these files inside
Program to use printer that accepts STL files
Filament
Ruler
Task cards and Inventory Log

title: Gimbal Holder for Feiyutech Mini3D Drone

description.text:
I saw the GoPro Karma and felt like the killer feature was the Gimbal Stabilizer could be taken off the Drone and held like a normal one as you walk around - cool feature!

The Feiyutech Mini3D is a cool and relatively cheap piece of kit you can mount on to a drone. I took it a step further and made this mount to be able to use it by yourself.

I learned a lot in OpenSCAD to make this design be possible - and I've tried to allow settings for a range of t hings like the size of the battery compatment and your velcro width.

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

25 Percent

Notes:

As long as you use Supports to hold the structure and lay it flat (rounded side should be facing upward).

The Supports will hold up the battery compartment.

The uploaded STLs here are based on the dimensions for this battery.
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__19885__Turnigy_1000mAh_2S_20C_Lipo_Pack_AU_Warehouse_.html

It's run for about two hours now, I'll need to do better stamina testing another time.

I recommend you use the OpenSCAD file to make an adjusted version for your own battery you will be using.

Get a Velcro strap (normal size is 220mm), and start by routing it through the two handle halves. with it snugly in place, it should hold the battery in. Continue routing through the gimbal to attach it, and you may need to get creative with the velcro attachment but it does work.

Lots of revisions in OpenSCAD! The file could do with some cleaning up, but uses a bunch of modules to create the end result. I want it to be usable by someone else with a different size battery (and maybe in the future different Gimbal on the top!

The Top Mount Attachment

The top mount attachment (Yellow in one of the pictures here) is an attempt to make a design that could hold the Xiaomi Yi even stronger, and be adaptable to any other kind of gimbal that could sit on top.

It has a secondary purpose of letting you fit electronics in it - I've used an Arduino Pro Mini with headers controlling (via PWM) the pan/tilt/yaw and Mode of the gimbal. Makes it much more practical this way.

I've uploaded the code needed and documented that process more here: https://github.com/SuperRoach/GimbalArduinoController

comments.text: Have you thought on making a nice 3D printed shell for the mounts - right now it looks like Frankenstein - nice holder + standard mounts. I think you can overcome this.
comments.author: Japim

comments.text: Did you see the picture with the yellow mount? I thought it didn't look too bad, and part of the bulkiness was having a large base. I guess i could taper off the front bottom bit, but there doesn't seem to be the demand for it - I don't know if anyone has made the rev 2
